sub_topic: Interpolation and extrapolation of data using Lagrange polynomials
message_1:
Suppose you are given the following table of values:

    
|   x  | f(x) |
|------|------|
|  1   |  3   |
|  2   |  5   |
|  5   |  2   |
|  7   |  6   |
|  9   |  1   |

Using Lagrange interpolation, what is the estimated value of f(3)?
message_2:
To estimate the value of f(3) using Lagrange interpolation, we will use the given data points to construct the Lagrange polynomial and then evaluate it at x = 3.

The Lagrange polynomial is given by:

L(x) = f(x_1) * l_1(x) + f(x_2) * l_2(x) + ... + f(x_n) * l_n(x)

where l_i(x) = ((x - x_1) * (x - x_2) * ... * (x - x_(i-1)) * (x - x_(i+1)) * ... * (x - x_n)) / ((x_i - x_1) * (x_i - x_2) * ... * (x_i - x_(i-1)) * (x_i - x_(i+1)) * ... * (x_i - x_n))

For our given data points, we have:

l_1(x) = ((x - 2) * (x - 5) * (x - 7) * (x - 9)) / ((1 - 2) * (1 - 5) * (1 - 7) * (1 - 9))
l_2(x) = ((x - 1) * (x - 5) * (x - 7) * (x - 9)) / ((2 - 1) * (2 - 5) * (2 - 7) * (2 - 9))
l_3(x) = ((x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 7) * (x - 9)) / ((5 - 1) * (5 - 2) * (5 - 7) * (5 - 9))
l_4(x) = ((x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 5) * (x - 9)) / ((7 - 1) * (7 - 2) * (7 - 5) * (7 - 9))
l_5(x) = ((x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 5) * (x - 7)) / ((9 - 1) * (9 - 2) * (9 - 5) * (9 - 7))

Now, we can construct the Lagrange polynomial L(x):

L(x) = 3 * l_1(x) + 5 * l_2(x) + 2 * l_3(x) + 6 * l_4(x) + 1 * l_5(x)

To find the estimated value of f(3), we evaluate L(3):

L(3) = 3 * l_1(3) + 5 * l_2(3) + 2 * l_3(3) + 6 * l_4(3) + 1 * l_5(3)

L(3) ≈ 3 * (-0.5) + 5 * 1.5 + 2 * (-0.5) + 6 * 0.5 + 1 * (-0.5)
L(3) ≈ -1.5 + 7.5 - 1 + 3 - 0.5
L(3) ≈ 7.5

So, the estimated value of f(3) using Lagrange interpolation is approximately 7.5.
